PM11:04am

Macquarie can explain

PM11:05am

China’s preliminary commodity trade data for February made interesting reading. On one hand, iron ore and coal imports remained strong, while copper concentrate imports recovered after a weak January . On this side, the Chinese commodity business model seems very normal, with plentiful appetite to soak up raw materials. However, the other side of the model – exporting finished products – was very weak in February, with annualised steel and aluminium export volumes the lowest since early 2014 – something we discussed in this note.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Of course, Chinese trade data can always be unusual around Chinese New Year. But shifts tend to impact imports and exports equally, and taking combined January-February data into account paints the same picture. Such an imbalance can point to stronger domestic demand. However, it can also point to inventory build, which has certainly been the case for steel, aluminium and copper. Demand now needs to come through strongly to pull this material through the chain, but physical indicators don’t point to this happening as of yet. Lower Chinese metal exports also mean less deflationary pressure being shipped to international markets, helping reference prices and supporting the reflation push, for now at least.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Our view: With the CEO leadership transition complete at RIO as well as the company reaching the end of its recent deleveraging chapter, Chairman Jan Du Plessis’ decision to step down after eight years, before the end of 2017, is understandable. The intended resignation will mean significant change at the head of the board in Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton and Anglo American, all at the same time. Although these passing of the batons’ should be relatively seamless, this does place some transitory uncertainty in regards to strategies, especially around M&A. Albeit marginal, this should increase the propensity for the big miners to take the easy route for the time being, avoid controversial capital allocation decisions and pay out higher dividends.

BE11:10am

Unrelated, we take this opportunity to point out the relationship between oil and iron ore. Clearly the oil price and its global importance is the driver, hence yesterday’s drop in oil prices should be influencing iron ore as well. A lower iron price normally means lower USD trade deficit, which usually means a stronger dollar. The lower oil price not only then causes commodity currencies to fall but also lowers input costs. Although on a headline basis this should be good for the miners, this also weakens cost curve support. And then there is also the question of whether oil price weakness is related to demand. Regardless, the relationship has been a close one historically.

With Chinese steel margins edging back from recent highs, the long-awaited iron ore price pullback could be upon us. We remain fundamentally bullish on iron ore markets, especially through H1 this year from a supply/demand/restocking perspective, but the oil price weakness could cause a further short-term sell off in prices.

PM11:18am

What's the chart trying to say?

BE11:18am

That's SocGen, which tells anyone knowledgeable of the science of chartism that there's a pivotal support at $50.60/50.00

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Here we go.

BE11:18am

Brent gave a break below the triangle pattern within which it was constricted since early January at $54.74 and this level also coincides with the weekly Moving Average. The correction has deepened and almost fetched the earlier highlighted support at $52.00/51.70, the lower band of a short-term down channel and the 61.8% retracement of the up move that occurred form last November to last December.

BE11:18am

Weekly RSI indicator is now closing in on a 1-year channel floor (horizontal blue line) and emphasizes the proximity of crucial supports, such as $51.70 and more importantly $50.60/50.00. Indeed, $50.60/50.00 appears pivotal as it represents the uptrend in force since January 2016 cyclical lows ($27.29) and the 38.2% retracement of the following uptrend. Thus, the current correction appears to be transitory and embedded within the overall uptrend, so long $50.60/50.00 holds. In an alternative scenario, a break below $50.60/50.00 would prompt accrued negative signals and mean a prolonged correction to last November low and also March 2016 high at $46.82, and to $45.14, last August low and the 61.8% of the whole uptrend.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Thus, near term levels are standing out at $51.70 and $54.74, and it will take a break above the latter i.e. the reintegration within the previous range for Brent to stage a rebound initially towards $55.75 and then to the short-term channel upper band at $56.75/57.00.
$53.86 is an immediate resistance.

BE11:18am

Obviously!

BE11:18am

11:18 am
BE11:19am

So to recap, there's a constricted triangle pattern with support at the lower band of a short-term down channel.

BE11:19am

Which means the current correction appears transitory and embedded within the overall uptrend ...

BE11:19am

..... Providing it goes up.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

But not if it goes down.

BE11:19am

If it goes down, the accrued negative signals mean a prolonged correction.

BE11:19am

So it'll go up or down. To conclude.

Price looks okay. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:22am

Shell's share of the assets disposed generated $0.5bn of cash
flow in 2016 and $0.3bn of FCF. Therefore, the $8.5bn transaction values these assets at 17x 2016 cash flow and a 3.5% 2016 FCF yield. Shell's share of production was ~168 kb/d last year, implying a value of ~$50,600 per flowing barrel. Per 2P barrel of reserves, the valuation is ~$4.9/bbl. For reference, Suncor's acquisition of various oil sands assets from Murphy Oil last year was done at a valuation of $3.6 per 2P barrel of reserves and $40,200 per flowing barrel. Suncor's acquisition of the company Canadian Oil Sands, also last year, was done at $4.2 per 2P barrel and $63,700 per flowing barrel. Against these comparisons, the valuation that Shell has achieved looks attractive. Also, WoodMackenzie's models value Shell's position in Canada at $4.2bn, assuming $60/bbl by 2020, which again suggests this transaction is value accretive for Shell.

BE11:23am

At end 2016, Shell carried $73bn of debt, implying a gearing ratio
of 28%. This transaction effectively lowers Shell's gearing by ~200bp.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Balance sheet reduction and simplification of Shell's corporate
structure are both catalysts that we expect will lead to a further contraction of Shell's elevated dividend yield of ~7.2%. The transaction announced today fits in that strategy and is an important step forward, in our view.

BE11:33am

11:33 am

BE11:33am

A more cautious consumer

BE11:33am

11:33 am

BE11:34am

Here's Canaccord ......

BE11:34am

We do not expect FY17 consensus to change at this stage. Domino's is acquiring the 51% shareholding in Pizza Pizza Norway from the Iceland group, and is increasing its stake in the Iceland business from 49% to 51% (dependent on Central Bank of Iceland approval). The result is that Domino's will hold a controlling share in the Norway, Sweden and Iceland Domino's businesses ahead of schedule.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Looking forward, expansionary sales will become increasingly important in driving profits and Domino's plans to double its store count (ex Germany) in the next decade to c.2,000 stores by growing at c.100 stores pa with the UK accounting for 80% of the growth. The UK growth strategy breaks down into two elements: store splits and new stores. It plans to double the store count in London, where it has just 121 stores, to put it on a par with New York for store density. The international programme should deliver the balance of growth; this is more complex (hence the JV route) and will take longer to come through as the markets are less developed.

BE11:34am

Domino's recently negotiated a new £175m five-year revolver and aims to run the business with a net debt/EBITDA ratio of up to 1.25x which would give Domino's considerable fire power: (1) to build new commissaries and its international strategy faster and (2) to increase returns to shareholders. We are not keen on the concept of using debt to fund share buybacks but the facility could be useful in a market slowdown.

BE11:35am

And Credit Suisse ..............

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Trimming DCF based target price: Given a more subdued period of trading (Q3/Q4/1st 9wks 2017), we lower our medium term LFL assumption to 4% from 5% noting the impact of more splits should be lapped within the year. This leaves our DCF yielding 455p, our new target price, and with 18% potential upside we maintain an Outperform rating.

BE11:35am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:35am

As we said last week: one cannot expect LFL sales to grow by double-digits forever or for new stores’ average sales not to contract; and to partially compensate this in the investment case, excess cash generation should be recycled into overseas expansion and share buybacks. However, we did not expect LFL sales to fall below our 3% forecast assumption.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We've argued before that Domino's surge pricing model is great, but is also a potential victim of smarter consumers.

BE11:36am

As in, you can buy two cheap pizzas when you don't really want them or one expensive one when you do.

BE11:37am

Alternatively, you can buy two cheap pizzas from Domino's when you don't really want them, or one cheap one from your local place when you do.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

It's a competitive market out there and surge pricing only really works with a defacto monopoly, or a drunk consumer.

BE11:37am

Domino's has the latter, but not the former.

PM11:38am

There was a request for some ECB grey earlier

PM11:38am

PM11:38am

He'll be under a lot of pressure to talk abut tightening at some stage

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Let me get some UBS

PM11:39am

This is from last week -- but a useful preview. And nothing much has changed since it was written

PM11:39am

Reinhard Cluse

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Will the ECB turn more hawkish in reaction to strong data?
The ECB meeting next week (9 March) will take place against the background of impressively strong growth and sentiment data as well as a substantial pick up in headline inflation. We believe ECB President Draghi will have to muster all of his communication skills to push back against suggestions that the ECB should turn more hawkish. We think the ECB will not, at this stage, drop its interest rate easing bias, but we suspect it might not extend the TLTRO-2 term funding scheme, the last auction of which is scheduled for 20-23 March.

PM11:39am

ECB likely to adjust communication gradually ahead of taper decision on 7 Sept
Our call remains that the ECB will buy assets worth €60bn from April to December 2017, as announced last December, but start to taper QE as of January 2018, with a decision likely due on 7 September. Aware of the risk of triggering a "tantrum" in the markets, we expect the ECB to "tighten" its communication gradually over the coming months, particularly as uncertainty around the Dutch and French elections dissipates. Given solid data and potential scarcity of assets available for QE, we now believe that tapering in 2018 will happen over 6-9 months rather than 12 months. This also implies a "risk" that the first rate hike might come earlier than our base-case scenario of 2019, but in any event only after QE has come to an end.

PM11:39am

New ECB macro projections: inflation forecast likely to be revised up
The ECB's staff macro projections from December were already quite bullish on growth (1.7/1.6% for 2017-2019) and we do not see much room for further upgrades. However, we expect the ECB to revise its inflation forecast visibly upwards, from 1.3% to 1.6% for 2017, with upside risk also for the 2018/2019 projection of 1.5/1.7%

11:39 am
PM11:40am

Rates Strategy: ECB unlikely to alleviate collateral shortage meaningfully
We do not expect fundamental policy changes at the current stage, but the ECB should become more hawkish towards H2. A withdrawal of the ECB accommodation during 2018 should lead to a term premium increase for Bund yields. For this meeting, the collateral shortage discussion will be in focus, after the rally in the German front-end. Meaningful action is less likely and the securities lending programme can only really soothe liquidity concerns, in our view. German front-end yields will remain structurally low and swap spreads wide. The ECB's PSPP issue(r) limit makes tapering inevitable and we have a closer look at when limits will be reached in this note.

PM11:40am

last bit

PM11:40am

Corporate Credit: No changes expected for CSPP
We do not expect any changes to the Corporate Sector Purchase Programme and our view remains that once the ECB slows asset purchases to €60bn from €80bn per month in April, corporate purchase dynamics would follow suit: to €6bn from €8bn per month. To date, CSPP purchases total €66.6bn, with an aggregated total return of +1.00% in Feb-17 vs -0.73% in Jan-17. On a total return basis, this has been the best month since Jul-16. Bonds purchased under CSPP have underperformed the broad index (iBoxx EUR IG Non-fin Senior index) that returned 1.29% in February.
Reinhard Cluse

11:43 am

PM11:43am

Ed Hammond

PM11:43am

11:44 am
BE11:44am

..... active talks, however, seem to have been so brief they can be measured in minutes rather than days.

BE11:44am

Still. Akzo's doing a Unilever and shaking itself up. Here's Credit Suisse to explain the logic there.

BE11:45am

Spinning off the Specialty Chemicals business makes strategic sense. This is premised upon: 1) Limited operational overlap between Specialty Chemicals and Paints/Coatings segments; 2) Multiple chemistries across Akzo’s Specialty Chemicals business (chlor alkali, salt, chelates, peroxides, ethylene amides) suggests it is challenging to find one buyer for these assets; 3) Significant improvement in business free cash flow suggests the Paints/Coatings segments are less reliant on the cash generated from the Chemicals business. The reduction/derisking of the pension liability and low balance sheet leverage (FY17F ND/EBITDA 0.3x) further reduces financial risk; 4) Unlocking value: Akzo’s Chlor Alkali spreads (within Specialty Chemicals) are benefiting from favourable (regulatory assisted) market conditions – supporting an improved earnings outlook. For Specialty Chemicals our SOTP applies a 10% discount to key peers (and a 25% discount to core European Chemicals - implied enterprise value ~€7bn) – which suggests sufficient size/scale to pursue a spin off. Importantly, divesting/spinning the Specialty Chemicals business and becoming a paints/coatings pure play may ultimately make AkzoNobel a more attractive takeover candidate.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And Jefferies.

BE11:46am

While the rejection is fairly strident, we believe many of the
potential concerns could be addressed--with valuation being the most significant hurdle. We estimate PPG could offer €93.50/share and achieve a 6% ROIC in FY3, comparable with other recent chemicals deals, and still be greater than $0.60/share FCF accretive. If synergy assumptions are lifted to 6%, we estimate PPG could offer €106. The less stringent goal of FCF accretion would enable an offer as high as €116 (5% ROIC in FY3 after synergies).

BE11:46am

What Is Plan B? We believe the proposal fits well with PPG's strategic goals and self-identity, which emphasizes products that are critical to improving the function or appearance of a substrate, at a low incremental cost--with a focus on industrial, aerospace, and automotive markets. We believe it remains an open question whether acquisitions in intermediate and functional chemicals would be a viable alternative. We do not expect a dramatic turn in capital returns to shareholders near-term.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Rejection " leaves a small window for PPG to return with a higher offer", they say. Which it does, certainly.

BE11:47am

UBS .......

BE11:47am

In pictures. They'll explain in a moment.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

BE11:48am

BE11:48am

Looking Fig 2 and 3 we believe there would be potentially anti-trust issues in the following areas - European (deco) market, particularly the UK, France and Belgium; Aerospace coatings (#1 and #2); Protective and Marine (#1 and #3); Auto Refinish (#2 and #3); Packaging (#2 and #3). This would suggest that the competition authorities would analyse this combination closely. At the end of 2016 Akzo Nobel pension deficit was €2.3bn with the gross liability of €17bn, while management has significantly de-risked the pension exposure a 25bps change to the discount risk changes the gross liability by ~€1.3bn or an increase of 1 year to longevity increases the gross liability ~ €0.7m (based on 2016 annual report).

11:49 am

BE11:49am

The combination of both companies would results in sales of $32bn of sales and $5.1bn of EBITDA based on our 2018 forecasts and we estimate cost savings are ~5% of Akzo Nobel's sales (the average in the Chemicals sector historically and is only slightly above the EBITDA margin gap of c3.5% in 2018E).

11:50 am
undefined
PM11:51am

Mention of CS reminds me that they have some new fangled risk monitor thing out today

PM11:51am

Europe is about to embark on a defining political period as upcoming elections in founding nations may reshape the EU political landscape and trigger a higher risk premium in markets. Credit Suisse has developed a Risk Barometer, which will be regularly updated, to gauge what level of ‘EU/euro’ risk is priced in across markets. The Barometer, along with an outline of three possible political scenarios, will help investors navigate through this period starting with the Dutch election and finishing with the German federal election. It provides a quick way to assess the level of concern about systemic risk discounted by European capital markets.

11:51 am

BE11:54am

BE11:54am

Morgan Stanley says .....

11:54 am
BE11:55am

This is a fairly routine result release, given that on January 10th
Morrison updated its PBT guidance to a fairly narrow range (£330-340m) and updated its net debt guidance. That said, Q4 LFL sales came in a touch below expectations, the outlook section does not contain much 'n ew news' apart from a comment on increasing Depreciation charges in FY18 (by £30m) and capex expectations of £450-500m in FY18 (a step up vs. FY17 and above mid-term guidance of £400-450m). Overall, although we await more from the company at the analyst meeting today, we do not expect the release to lead to consensus upgrades at this point. Hence, given the good run for the shares last year (and to some extent YTD) leaving them on a rich valuation (21x CY17e P/E and 15x CY17e EBIT), we believe this release does not contain much for the bulls to sink their teeth into.

BE11:59am

The final results were broadly in line with expectations, with a
c40% fall in PBT driven by a weaker transaction market and
investment in the business. Year-end net debt/EBITDA was 2.9x
and today’s proposed placing of c10% of the share capital will
help improve this position. The outlook remains tricky, with
management expecting both transactions and house prices to be
lower this year and further cost savings announced to mitigate
this. Our forecasts are under review and the shares remain ones
to avoid, in our view.

BE11:59am

The key focus today is on the balance sheet, with net debt in the
year increasing by £69m to £248m, with net debt/EBITDA of 2.97x. To reinforce the balance sheet, a proposed placing of 9.9% of the share capital (21.6m shares) has been announced and the group is also continuing with the strategic review of the commercial business (Lambert Smith Hampton), which should see further cash inflow from a sale before the end of the year. Management is targeting year-end leverage of c2x and has maintained its longerterm target of 1.5-2.0x.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

(@Upaswellasdown: I think it was floated as a rollup of local estate agents.)

BE12:00pm

Plenty of moving parts to consider after today’s announcement but, in short, the group is expecting a “resilient performance” in 2017. Given the cost savings announced, and the market headwinds, our existing PBT forecast of £51m (implying a modest fall on 2016) feels reasonable at this stage, although we will firm up our numbers after today’s analyst meeting. Based on our current forecasts and accounting for the proposed placing of c10% of the share capital, the shares trade on a 2017 PE of c11x. The dividend has been rebased to pay out between 30-35% of earnings. While uncertainty around trading, the shape of the business and the balance sheet persists, we believe the shares remain ones to avoid.
